The Town Hall is saddened to hear of the passing of actress and singer Diahann Carroll. We are honored to have had her perform at Town Hall on Feb 21, 1960, as part of the Morningside Mental Health Clinic. Which brought together the biggest names in entertainment to fund raise for the interracial, non-sectarian adult treatment program. She performed this night alongside hosts  Sidney Poitier and Wendy Barrie with Harry Belafonte, Miriam Makeba, Ossie Davis, and Don Shirley. Photo by Gene Howard.
.
.
.

Our #WCW #WomanCrushWednesday is Debbie Harry! Harry is a seminal rock-n-roll figure, complex songstress, incandescent front woman, actor and fashion icon. She has gone from an irreverent Lower East Side punk goddess to a bona fide international ambassador of New York cool. Along her journey she has brought the worlds  of rock, punk, disco and ska together with “Heart of Glass” and “Call  Me” and broke ground by combining hip-hop and pop on “Rapture.” On Mon. Sept 30 celebrate the release of her new memoir FACE IT at The Town Hall with her and Blondie cofounder Chris Stein and director Rob Roth. Photo: Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty
Ticket link in bio.

As we celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month we remember the December 25, 1947 concert when Cuban percussionist and multi-hyphenate artist Chano Pozo performed with Dizzy Gillespie, cementing their collaboration in the annals of Afro-Cuban Jazz and Jazz history. In 1981, Gillespie returned to the hall to pay tribute to Pozo and Afro-Cuban Jazz. Legends Mario Bauza and Paquita D'Riveira joined.

On this day in 1959 Nina Simone made her concert hall debut at The Town Hall in New York City. Simone wrote in her autobiography: "I stood in the wings and looked out at the audience, sitting in neat rows with no drinks in their hands, no cigarette girls walking up and down to distract them, and no out-of-tune piano to ruin my performance. The MC called my name and I walked on like an Egyptian queen - slow, calm and serious.  Colpix recorded the concert and released it as Nina Simone at Town Hall, so if you don't believe me you can listen for yourself. The reviews were the best I had ever had. I was a sensation. An overnight success, like in the movies." Listen to the genius Nina Simone on piano and vocals on Nina Simone at Town Hall. Link to our Spotify in bio.
.
.
.

Shortly after the publication of his controversial Harper's article “The Prisoner of Sex,” Norman Mailer took the stage at Town Hall for a debate against a diverse grouping of feminists: Jacqueline Ceballos, Germaine Greer, Jill Johnston and Diana Trilling. Celaballos, President of the New York Chapter of the National Organization for Women, was interrupted by a screaming Gregory Corso, writer Greer was accused of elitism by protesters in and outside of the hall, and Johnston, a lesbian cultural critic kissed and rolled around with two women onstage. Johnston, then a columnist for The Village Voice prepared a free wheeling speech on lesbianism before being joined onstage by the two women. Mailer's response? "You know, it's great that you pay $25 to see three dirty overalls on the floor," and "Come on, Jill. Be a lady." Betty Friedan and Susan Sontag spoke from the crowd, as Arthur Schlesinger, Cynthia Ozick, Anatole Broyard and other famous New Yorkers watched.  In 1979, Chris Hegedus and D A Pennebaker released a documentary about the evening entitled 'Town Bloody Hall." .
.
.
.

In 1967, Jack Doroshow aka Flawless Sabrina produced a legendary drag pageant at The Town Hall. It was documented in the film, "The Queen," which was selected for Cannes Film Festival in 1968 and came to be regarded as a landmark of queer culture. Over the years Flawless served as mother and mentor to hundreds of artists and musicians. Fifty years after the release of "The Queen," on May 10, 2018; The Town Hall and the children of Flawless Mother Sabrina celebrated their legacy. This celebration featured Taylor Mac,  Justin Vivian Bond, The House of Labeija and more.
.
.
.

On Sale now! On July 21st take One Giant Leap. New York Times presents a look back Apollo 11 and the Moon Landing 50 Years On. 
Renowned astronauts and stars of stage and screen participate in this soaring Times event commemorating the 50th anniversary of Apollo 11 and humankind’s first steps on the moon.

The evening will feature the reading of a short play by Tony Award-winning author J.T. Rogers. Commissioned specifically for this event, the play weaves together transcripts of the Apollo 11 mission, Times coverage from the period and excerpts from recent interviews. The performers who will bring these moments to life include: Lauren Ambrose, Jeff Daniels, Danai Gurira, LaTanya Richardson Jackson, Samuel L. Jackson, Dakin Matthews, and Arian Moayed. Directed by Tony winner Bartlett Sher and produced by Cambra Overend. 
Following the reading, Michael Barbaro of “The Daily” will host a conversation with Michael Collins, command module pilot on Apollo 11, Peggy Whitson, the first female commander of the International Space Station, and Poppy Northcutt, the first female engineer to work in NASA’s Mission Control. Ticket link in bio.
.
.

It's too explosive for indoor consumption; we're taking Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song outdoors! Burnt Sugar Arkestra presents Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Remix, Redux & Requiem is moving from The Town Hall to Fort Greene Park, Thursday May 30, 8pm, and free to the public. 
The Town Hall and Rooftop Films present this special production, free to the public, outdoors! No persons under the age of 17 will be admitted.
.
.
.

The 1971 release of Melvin Van Peebles' "Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song" was a cinematic milestone on multiple levels. Van Peebles financed, wrote, starred in, edited, produced and distributed the film. He also composed the score himself and got a band of upstarts to play his tunes for the soundtrack. That group became more well-known a couple years later as Earth Wind & Fire. Within months of release, Sweetback's became the most successful independent feature in American film history. In every aspect of representing Black communal culture and radical resistance, Sweetback's was a breakthrough work of protest-art and soul.

On May 30th, Burnt Sugar the Arkestra Chamber revisit the Van Peebles compositions, performing a live score remix, while a silent screening of "Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song" is projected onto the Town Hall stage. Actors and band members read from the original script while Burnt Sugar surgically operates on Van Peebles' music via their remixological deployment of the late Butch Morris’ patented “Conduction" system for improvising ensembles. They “caramelized” for two souled-out performances at the Sons d’hiver Festival in 2010 and now present the North American + NYC premiere. .
.
.

#burntsugar #arkestra #arkestrachamber #funk #jazz #reggae #soul #hiphop #vernonreid #petecosey #rooftopfilms #brooklyn #whattodo #nyc #newyorkcity

Happy Earth Day! On Sept. 17 2017, The 9th Equator Prize Award Ceremony were held at The Town Hall.  Leading thinkers, policy-makers, business and civil society leaders from around the globe gathered at the gala. Hosted by the Equator Initiative partnership, to recognize and celebrate the extraordinary initiatives and innovations brought about by indigenous peoples and local communities from 12 countries.

15 winners were awarded a cash prize of US$10,000 each for their significant work to create scalable,  nature-based solutions to address biodiversity conservation, climate change adaptation, disaster risk reduction, gender empowerment, land rights, and food and water security. Read on here: http://bit.ly/2GDdaQd

Is your organization in need of summer interns? The Town Hall is looking for arts organizations to partner with for our 2019 Summer Internship Program. 11/28/1936 Alice Tully, U.S. singer, music promoter, and philanthropist, for whom the famous Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center is named, performed here at Town Hall. A lifelong patron of the arts, she donated millions of dollars throughout her life, often anonymously. Tully was awarded both the Handel Medallion and The National Medal of the Arts for her contributions to the cultural and artistic climate of New York City. .
.
.

DEC 6, 1934.  Edna St. Vincent Millay gave a series of readings from her poems at Town Hall under the auspices of the League for Political Education. Famous for works like "Euclid alone has looked on Beauty bare" ,"Renascence" and "First Fig." She received the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry in 1923, the third woman to win the award for poetry, and was also known for her feminist activism. .

My candle burns at both ends;
It will not last the night;
But ah, my foes, and oh, my friends—
It gives a lovely light! "First Fig"
.

December 30, 1935; Marian Anderson held her New York debut at The Town Hall. Anderson was previously denied an operatic career due to discrimination against African-Americans. That evening, Anderson performed alongside Kosti Vehanen at the piano, and the program included Haendel, Schubert, and Sibelius compositions along with others, such as Roland Hayes’ “City called Heaven.” Her New York debut would lead to Anderson being the first African-American to later perform at New York’s Metropolitan Opera. .
.
.

2/23/1999. Blondie's first New York show in 17 years was at The Town Hall (released later as Blondie Live). Before the Cardigans, before No Doubt, before Madonna, there was Blondie: the New Wave band with a sultry, cagey blonde at its center. From 1975 until its breakup in 1982, Blondie found commercial shape for the sounds of downtown New York night life. Its songs moved from ironic revisions of girl-group rock to urgent punk-rock to trim New Wave pop to disco, reggae and early rap. Deborah Harry, Blondie's singer and main lyricist, tucked an adult attitude between the pop hooks.
.
.
.

1/1/1948. "A concert in memory of Bessie Smith, celebrated blues singer, was presented by the Friends of Jazz at Town Hall for the benefit of the United Negro and Allied Veterans of America. Many noted jazz players and singers, some of whom appeared with Miss Smith in clubs and on records. took part in the program, which was given under the direction of Bernard Katz."- NYT. Smith would be buried in an unmarked grave until Janis Joplin years later helped create a memorial. In 1984 Smith was inducted into the Women's Hall of Fame.

Feb 28, 1959. The Thelonious Monk Orchestra recorded their historic performance at The Town Hall. On this evening, Monk introduced a new band, after previously being known to mostly lead smaller ones. For this night, ten musicians accompanied Monk. The Thelonious Monk Orchestra at Town Hall was originally released in 1959 and featured Hall Overton’s arrangements on Monk’s compositions. The iconic show also included tuba player Jay McAllister, tenor-sax player Charlie Rouse, and bassist Sam Jones, among others. .
.
.

Nov. 8th 1947. Recorded Live at The Town Hall was "One Night Stand The Town Hall Concert 1947," which featured Sarah Vaughan and the Lester Young sextet. The CD was not released until 1997 and featured music from the previously unreleased Town Hall concert. Other performers included the likes of a young Roy Haynes, trumpeter Shorty McConnell, and bassist Rodney Richardson.

November 19, 1939. Soprano recitalist Dorothy Maynor held her Town Hall debut. The recital sold-out more than a week in advance and marked her formal debut. Nearly a year later, Maynor was awarded the Town Hall Endowment Series Award by New York music critics. In 1975, Maynor, never able to sing at New York's Metropolitan Opera, became the first African-American to join its board of directors. She would also go on to found the Harlem School of the Arts. Photo by Robert Capa of Maynor with Paul Robeson following her debut.
.
.
.

Feb. 17. 1944
During a 1944 broadcast of Town Meeting of the Air, Langston Hughes, John Temple Graves II, Carey McWilliams, and James E. Shepard strived to face the race question. Each side of the debate was represented by both a black and a white speaker, through which Hughes and McWilliams stated that segregation must end. The debaters conducted a thoughtful discussion that did inspire people across the U.S. to engage in conversations about race.
.
.
.

Oct 22 '17: Roberta Flack was honored as Town Hall's Friend of the Arts.  A humanitarian and mentor, Ms. Flack founded the Roberta Flack school of Music at the Hyde Leadership Charter School in the Bronx, which provides a free innovative and inspiring music education program to underprivileged students. She is one of the most beloved singers of our time, with hit songs "The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face," "Where Is The Love?," "Killing Me Softly With His Song," Feel Like Makin' Love," "The Closer I Get To You," and "Set The Night to Music."

Nov 15, 1964, Coretta Scott King debuted her Freedom Concert "Montgomery to Washington" at Town Hall. "I developed the "Freedom Concert" concept, where I narrated the story of the civil rights movement that we were involved in, and sang freedom songs in between the narrations that told the story of our struggle from Montgomery to Washington at that time. In 1964, I did my debut with my Freedom Concert at Town Hall"
.
.
.
.
.
.

Feb. 8th 1932. "Sergei Rachmaninoff's recital at the Town Hall last night was the third in the endowment series. The program included Mozart's Sonata 14, an old French gavotte and a gavotte by Gluck arranged by Pauer; a ballade, a nocturne, a rondo and a scherzo by Chopin; two preludes by the pianist, Liszt's "Valse oubliee" and "Voices of the Wood" and the Strauss-Tausig valse-caprice, "One Lives but Once.(NYT)" .
.
.

Town Hall History: Jan. 23, 1943
Eleanor Roosevelt Sparks Anti-Paralysis Campaign
"Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, at a rally in Town Hall yesterday, opened a nation-wide Women's Week in behalf of the fight against poliomyelitis, urging that women, particularly at this time, volunteer in the campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis." (NYT) This organization would later go on to become the March of Dimes.
.
.
.

On this date in Town Hall History: January 12, 1921 The Opening of Town Hall!
Founded by a group of suffragists (The League for Political Education) seeking to build a space where the people could be more informed voters, The Town Hall was built in 1921, designed by renowned architects McKim, Mead & White to reflect the democratic principles of the League. Box seats were eliminated and no seats had an obstructed view giving birth to the term "Not a bad seat in the house." Since then it has become a cultural institution in NYC. .
.
.

On this date in Town Hall history: Dec. 30th 1935, The great Marian Anderson performed at Town Hall, where she gave her first recital. Anderson, who faced racism and adversity throughout her career wowed critics at this performance. New York Times said "Let it be said at the outset: Marian Anderson has returned to her native land one of the great singers of our time. Her singing enchanted an audience that included singers. There was no doubt about it, she was mistress of all she surveyed. " .

On this date in Town Hall history: Frank Zappa and the Mothers of Invention played Town Hall on Dec. 22nd and 23rd in 1967. 
A show that the New York Times said "What began as the equivalent of an underground office party at Town Hall last night soon developed into both a very serious and experimental new-form concert, an equally irrevelent and satirical musical evening.
On stage was a nine-member pop-classical-rock-chamber orchestra called the Mothers of Invention. The Mother Superior, Frank Zappa, is a sort of compositional wizard turned zany who suggests a mix between Stravinsky and Groucho Marx, with a touch of Rasputin thrown in for flavor." .
.
.Photographer-Jay L. Handler

The Town Hall was built by the League for Political Education, whose fight for passage of the 19th Amendment (women's suffrage) led them 2 build a meeting space where ppl of every rank & station could be educated on the important issues of the day (dope). As the space was designed to reflect the democratic principles of the League, box seats were not included in the theater's design. This design principle gave birth to The Town Hall's long-standing mantra: "Not a bad seat in the house."
-
P.S. - During completion of the building the 19th Amendment was passed (women's right to vote), & on January 12, 1921 The Town Hall opened its doors & took on a double meaning: as a symbol of the victory sought by its founders, & as a spark for a new, more optimistic climate.
-

On April 12, 1963, #BobDylan had his breakout concert at The Town Hall. The concert is a masterpiece: A brilliant mix of originals from his album released a month later, Dylan played everything from Blowin in the Wind to rare, uncompleted protest songs like Hiding Too Long. The concert introduced to the world a young genius and a new era of folk music, and forecast a legacy to come. On Bob Dylan's birthday, Thursday May 24, the Town Hall Ensemble will pay tribute to Dylan and this legendary concert. More info to follow! Tix on sale Tuesday April 17th.

María Concepción Balboa Buika “Buika” from Majorca, Spain, daughter of African parents of the Bubi tribe (Equatorial Guinea) immersed and surrounded by multiple cultures throughout her life, had a variety of musical inﬂuences, from jazz and ﬂamenco to pop, soul and African polyrhythm; as she aﬃrmed, “My mother would listen and dance to many musical genres, she had a great record collection” . This eclectic upbringing shaped Buika’s ability to make music without limitations. During her 15-year recording career, her albums ﬂow seamlessly between pop, jazz, soul, reggae, afro beat, R&B and ﬂamenco. Equally diverse are her collaborators, which include Pat Metheny, Anoushka Shankar, Chick Corea, Niño Josele, Bebo and Chucho Valdés, Seal or Nelly Furtado to name a few. Filmmaker and longtime fan, Pedro Almodóvar, remarked about Buika, “Seeing her draw from such diﬀerent genres… Mix them all together with such grace and spontaneity, one cannot help but think that there is a brighter future as long as one can witness the boundless evolution of this inﬁnite performer”. @buikamusic @camilamezamusic

On this day in 1957 the Little Rock Nine, under heavily armed guard, entered Central High School to attend their first full day of classes. Their hard-won victory over segregration in Arkansas was met with protests by racist, angry mobs, nevertheless Ernest Green would become the first African American to graduate from Central High. The Little Rock Nine’s many contributions to society and American history have been acknowledged through the numerous awards and recognitions they have received, including the Congressional Gold Medal in 1999. #LittleRockNine Read more: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Rock_Nine

#GlennGould , a very young "Canadian Pianist", played his New York recital debut at Town Hall on January 11th, 1955. “I went out of my way to pick as odd a program as I could." Gould said, and despite a nervous attack of "fibrositis" that saw him soaking his arms in a sink backstage, "I was never so relaxed in my life as at my Town Hall debut in New York". He was offered a major contract with Columbia Records the next day; he would go on to create over 80 albums under the label. 
Gould's success followed a period of near total seclusion at his parents winter cottage on Lake Simcoe outside of Toronto. "The basic thing that I did at that time," he said, "was to rethink the way in which the piano ought to be played." | #musichistory #townhallnyc #nyc

October 30th 1934 | #ClaraRockmore, classical violin prodigy and a virtuoso performer of the #theremin, had her recital debut at the Town Hall with her sister, pianist Nadia Reisenberg in 1934. On her return to the Hall in 1938, the New York Post wrote "Last night in Town Hall a large audience sat enthralled while Clara Rockmore, assisted by Nadia Reisenberg at the piano, played a recital on the electrical instrument, the Theremin. The program included a Concerto in E minor by Nardini; the Franck Sonata in A major, and a group of pieces by Achron, Tchaikovsky, Ravel and Korngold. Standing before the cabinet of the instrument, with the speaker behind her, Miss Rockmore, in a manner suggestive of the supernatural, drew exquisite tones seemingly out of thin air. With no tangible point of contact with the Theremin she performed difficult scale passages and leaps with an astounding dexterity and precision. The instrument, which is not comparable to any other existing one, has a great range of pitch and dynamics and appears to possess no technical limits." | #townhallnyc #musichistory #townhallhistory

The Von Trapp Family, billed as the Trapp Family Choir performed at The Town Hall  on December 10th, 1938. The New York Times wrote:
"There was something unusually lovable and appealing about the modest, serious singers of this little family aggregation as they formed a close semicircle about their self-effacing director for their initial offering, the handsome Mme. von Trapp in simple black, and the youthful sisters garbed in black and white Austrian folk costumes enlivened with red ribbons. It was only natural to expect work of exceeding refinement from them, and one was not disappointed in this." | #townhallnyc #musichistory

On Tuesday we lost board member and Town Hall Foundation Trustee, Hon. Milton Mollen. He was 97. And what a life! Taken prisoner during WWII by the Germans when his plane was shot down over France, he escaped his captors in April 1945 and returned home to pursue law. As a judge on NY's State Supreme court, he tirelessly pursued police corruption, and later founded the New York office of Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services. The Town Hall sends its deepest sympathies to friends and family.

Judy Collins dragged a petrified #LeonardCohen onto the Town Hall stage in 1967 for his first public performance “He was nervous,” recalled Collins, “and as I introduced him and brought him onstage in front of the enthusiastic full house, I could feel his hands shaking. But when he began to sing, the shaking left his voice and he steadied, and people began to revel in the beauty of ‘Suzanne.’ About halfway through the song, blaming what he later said was a broken string, he stopped and walked offstage. I went back on with him and we finished the song together. People went wild.” #MusicHistory #TownHallHistory #NYCHistory

In November 1954, #LeontynePrice made her recital debut at Town Hall with a program that featured the New York premiere of Samuel Barber's cycle Hermit Songs, with the composer at the piano. Her recording debut came in 1959 with A Program of Song, an intimate, arresting performance captured live, also at the Town Hall. Time magazine called her voice "Rich, supple and shining, it was in its prime capable of effortlessly soaring from a smoky mezzo to the pure soprano gold of a perfectly spun high C." | #TownHallHistory #BlackHistoryFacts #opera

1929: Marian Anderson made her first recital appearance at The Town Hall. After being turned away by all-white Philadelphia music schools, she pursued her career in Europe, going on to win critical acclaim and the admiration of luminaries like Sibelius and Einstein. Even with her celebrity status, as she toured the United States she faced continual discrimination from venues, restaurants and hotels; the Town Hall was still the only venue that would welcome her for a triumphant return performance in 1935. Despite being called "the voice of a century", it would be another two decades before she was permitted to perform at the Met. In 1939, the Daughters of the American Revolution refused to allow her to sing to an integrated audience. Eleanor Roosevelt promptly resigned from the organization; she and her husband stepped in to organize an open-air Easter concert with Marian performing on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. #blackhistoryfacts #TownHallHistory

Henry Butler is described by the The @nytimes as “percussive in his attack, ostentatious with his technique… the picture of stubborn mischief — and, not coincidentally, of New Orleans pianism... billowing whole-tone glissandi; furrowed, Monkish hiccups; boppish two-handed octaves; flare-ups of funk and Chopin.” 6/15 Butler and fellow #NewOrleans legend Dr. John perform together for the first time at The Town Hall.

Tomorrow 6/15! New Orleans legend Dr. John brings his unique blend of voodoo mysticism, funk, rhythm & blues, psychedelic rock and Creole roots to the Town Hall stage. Playing for the first time with Henry Butler. @pianobutler @aka_drjohn | Photo © James Demaria @jamesdemariapro |

Happy Birthday, Clara Rockmore! Clara performed at The Town Hall in 1938 in what could be considered her breakthrough performance. A master theremin player, she was one of the first performers to bring an electronic musical instrument to the mainstream classical world. Head to #GoogleDoodles to play the theremin yourself! #classicalmusic #theremin

"We pioneers cannot completely relax and sigh with satisfaction until planned parenthood has ceased to be a cause for which one has to fight, and becomes an accepted right of women throughout the world. Then and only then can we relax and say, 'The battle is won.'" - #MargaretSanger, Birth Control: Then and Now, 1944

On November 13, 1921 Margaret Sanger held the final meeting of the First American Birth Control Conference - an historic gathering of prominent scientists, physicians, demographers, eugenicists, social workers, birth control advocates and socialites - entitled "Birth Control: Is It Moral?" What has since been referred to as The Town Hall Raid, Sanger was arrested on stage, her freedom of speech actively suppressed by the Roman Catholic Archbishop Patrick J. Hayes who shut down the meeting through his emissary Monsignor Joseph P. Dineen. The raid was heavily publicized, prompting an enormous turnout at the postponed meeting on November 18, and catapulting the issue of birth control into public discourse. Sanger founded the American Birth Control League (ABCL) at the conference, which later became known as #PlannedParenthood. 📷:Salon/Benjamin Wheelock #feminism #NYC #heforshe #genderequality #herstory #PP #women #IWD2016 #InternationalWomensDay #iwd

Happy #InternationalWomensDay! "Ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free" | In 1894, New York State held a Convention to revise and amend their Constitution. Female suffragists, including #SusanBAnthony, presented 600,000 signatures on a petition to strike out the word “male” in Article II of the Constitution, which would grant women the right to vote. The New York State Senate rejected their petition. Later that year, six women - Eleanor Butler Sanders, Mary Putnam, Lee Haggin, Adele Fielde, Lucia Runkle, and Catherine Abbe - met to strategize about what to do next. The anti-suffragist sentiment in New York rested upon the premise that women, whose purview was limited to the household, lacked the knowledge and experience necessary to be voters. To counter that argument, these six women formed the League of Political Education to educate women and spark discourse on current issues. After a few years, they decided the League needed a permanent home, and contracted McKim, Mead & White (who designed the original Penn Station and Madison Square Garden II) to design a new building on 43rd Street, which was completed in 1921. They named it The Town Hall. #feminism #NYC #heforshe #genderequality #herstory #women #IWD2016

Today in Town Hall History: On February 21, 1950, Artie Shaw performed with The Little Orchestra Society. Widely recognized as jazz's greatest clarinetist, he performed "Concertante for Clarinet and Orchestra" by Norman Dello Joio. Artie led one of the most popular big bands in the 1930s and 40s, and is especially remembered for his recording #ColePorter's "Begin the Beguine." #123History

Every year Town Hall is privileged to honor our Friends of the Arts - those individuals or organizations whose contributions to the arts enrich our city's cultural life. On Sunday October 18, at the Princeton Club, Town Hall will hosted its 94th Annual Gala, and honored KT Sullivan and Paul Libin as this year’s Friends of the Arts. The festivities for the evening began with a concert featuring New Orleans musician Henry Butler followed by cocktails, dinner, and the awards presentation.
